------=_NextPart_000_025A_01CA1B2D.A50C85A0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Jason,
 
Thanks.  Yes, there is extra complexity in MPI.
 
There are two means of message passing in MPI -- broadcast, as you have
mentioned, and point-to-point.
 
I have been experimenting with using CPPNs to generate the point-to-point
connections for the compute fabric over the ob1 layer, as compared to say
the btl.
 
The complexity of configuring and running neuroevolution experiments may
actually be resolved by using HyperNEAT to configure itself.  Too soon to
really tell.
 
Ken Lloyd


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Jason
Gauci
Sent: Wednesday, August 12, 2009 8:54 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT - force reevaluation of population


  

The extra complexity of MPI lies in the fact that there's no infrastructure
in my code for communicating information to experiments running on other
PCs. You would have to write something that broadcasts a message to all PCs
letting them know fo the change to the environment.

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Ken Lloyd"
<kalloyd@...> wrote:
>
> Jason,
> 
> I'm using MPI (OpenMPI) for RDMA of parametric sections and populations.
> While this doesn't change the forward operations of the experiment, it
does
> change everything else. Is there something else I have overlooked?
> 
> Ken Lloyd
> 
> 
> _____ 
> 
> From: neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com
[mailto:neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com] On Behalf Of
Jason
> Gauci
> Sent: Tuesday, August 11, 2009 7:09 AM
> To: neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com
> Subject: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT - force reevaluation of population
> 
> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, Joshua
> Auerbach <joshua.auerbach@> wrote:
> >
> > I have a question for any of you that know the HyperNEAT code. 
> > Basically I am trying to incorporate changing environmental conditions 
> > into my algorithm such that when a certain criteria is met the 
> > environment I evaluate my evolved neural networks in is modified. When 
> > this happens I want to throw out the fitness of all the individuals in 
> > my population that were obtained from the old environment and force them

> > to be reevaluated in the new environment. Does anyone have a suggestion 
> > for how this can be done?
> > 
> > Thanks,
> > Josh
> >
> 
> Hey Josh,
> 
> The ExperimentRun::evaluatePopulation(...) function is the one that loops
> through the population and assigns fitness to all the individuals based on
> the experiments. There are several experiments so that the application can
> be multithreaded.
> 
> As long as you aren't using MPI, all you have to do to change an
experiment
> (or the environment, as you call it), is loop through all of your
> experiments in the ExperimentRun class, dynamically cast the experiment to
> your specific experiment class, and call some function that changes the
> experiment in the future.
> 
> It would be easiest to do this in between generations. In this case, you
> wouldn't have to worry about re-evaluating individuals who have already
> received a fitness, although I supposed it could be done anytime. If,
during
> a call to evaluatePopulation, the environment needs to be updated, you'll
> have to write some code to abort the population evaluation and start it
over
> again, to ensure that the entire generation of individuals is evaluated
the
> same.
> 
> Jason G.
>
